CarX Street for MacOS Tahoe on Mac Mini M-Series

CarX Street is one of those smaller games that is as good or better than you may have hoped before playing it. From the gameplay to the visuals and customization, CarX Street is a fantastic journey into the open-world car racing genre.

VISUALS
The visuals are superb for a game of this size. Long sight-lines and a large map make this game a blast to explore. Cars, modifications and the map make for a lot of lovely wasted time. Playing for hours at a time just exploring the landscape. When it comes to the cars, being able to create your own vision and see it drive down the road is spectacular. The camera feature makes this feel so worth your time. So many beautiful places to get lost in and take a few photos. Nice touch!

AUDIO
The audio is a bit of a mixed bag, but definitely on the higher end. The engine sounds are good, but the engine backfires pop to life and make it worth having a good audio system. Bass rumbles! The atmospheric audio is good also. Tire contact with different road and land materials always let you know whether you need to take it easy or hold down the accelerator.

GAMEPLAY
The gameplay feels great and learning each of the vehicles nuances makes for a learning experience for sure. It can be so satisfying when you get the grip knowledge needed for races and drifting. The sense of accomplishment as you modify and tune each vehicle is worth the price of admission in my opinion. Something the dev team really seems to understand.

CONTENT AND VALUE
Now, full disclosure, I purchased the game and all the DLC. But for the amount, I have zero regrets. Being a Mac gamer, I am sure there are many games in the racing arena that I am not able to play that Windows players can. But having this one in the arsenal is fantastic in my opinion. It's just that good on the Mac side. With limited choices, this one is a no-brainer for Mac gamers. If you like NFS and games like it, this is the one for you.

CLOSING
I appreciate that Carx Tech allowed this game to be available for MacOS as it fills a gap on the platform. Keep up the good work.

Within 2 days of gameplay, specifically 44 hours only, I learned that from level 1 to level 8, you won't be able to the Miata in the beginning of the game that you get for free to drift. After doing sprint, drift, and circuit missions, I learned quickly that these are a complete waste of time because getting in 1st place is nearly impossible; which is how you get the most CR (credits).

So, I shifted to delivering cars for cash. It starts off with rewarding you 5,000 CR. Once you deliver enough cars, you unlock the 15,000 CR deliveries and the cars are higher performance than the 5,000 CR ones. Then the 3rd rank of this business gives you $ which is the premium in-game currency that is used to buy higher-tier car upgrade parts, engine and transmission swaps, and occasionally bodykits that use this currency.

You can farm the $ currency once every 30 minutes. You can run two 15,000 CR missions per day. Then it turns into one 15,000 CR mission per 3 minutes. The 5,000 CR missions are infinite with no cooldown timer restriction. So you can spam these back to back. To pass the 3 minute timer quicker, it's best to drive to each location where the delivery starts on the map and by the time you get there you'll be able to run it right away.

So, the key tip for this game is to ignore the missions on the map, the campaign etc. And just focus on maxing out the rank of the car and box delivery businesses so that you can spam 5,000 and 15,000 CR and 20 $ currency missions back to back. 

Between level 1 and 8, you'll start to unlock the parts needed to make a car drift. This is when I sold the Miata, after it was finally able to go sideways consistently with the tuning I gave it, for a BMW. Used the BMW until like level 16-ish. Built an s18 alongside the BMW. Sold the BMW. Sold the s18. And now I have a honda civic type-r AWD and an Evo X swapped to RWD. With plans of building another RWD dedicated car without hard swapping the transmission.

It would make too much sense for that collectable to be hidden amongst cars in the parking lot, or on top of a parking garage, but no, instead it's randomly on the corner of some dirt road.
-Race lines are LAUGHABLE. They are terribly optimized both in placement and braking indications. I'm more often then not, not following the line because it's literally slower. Or the countless amount of times that the braking indication tells me to start braking way too late or way too early.
-Nitrous feels literally useless 90% of the time. Incredibly often, I'm blasting through my nitrous only to look at the car next to me maintaining the same speed as me. Literally the only use for it is coming out of corners to get back up to speed, but only if you know that your opponent is not in the middle of exiting a corner.

The Good

-A lot of races to play through

---{ PC Requirements }---
-I have a high end computer and maxing this game out entirely on 1440p causes no issues. I have my game locked to 165hz and don't seem to dip below. Game is definitely well optimized from what I can tell

---{ Game Size }---
Average, maybe even a little less so, which is a good thing

---{ Difficulty }---
Difficulty obviously scales, but I would say the game is not difficult. Most of the difficulty comes from frustration from the things I've complained about above (Poor AI, weird mix of arcade and realism, blown out brightness, useless NOS, etc). These things make the game difficult, but in a completely unrewarding game. I'm often met with challenge that just leaves me mad at the way the game is built, instead of me telling myself that I need to improve,

---{ Grind }---
Grind is pretty solid. No real complaints here. Standard racing game grind. Race to get money, use money to buy or upgrade cars to win more money from races. Usually, once you enter a club, you'll want to upgrade your car to the max of that class. By the time you win all the races, you'll have enough money to buy a new car and upgrade it for the next club, which is definitely a satisfying loop. It makes the goals for racing good, clear, and worth doing (instead of just freeroaming the map). Depending on how or why you bought this game, it could be a good or bad thing. However, as mentioned, I think the free roam is pretty underwhelming and dull, which makes the race grind the only real fun thing to do (which is fine, considering at it's core it is a racing game).


---{ Story }---
-If you're playing a racing game for the story, find another genre to play.
-With that being said, the club leaders and characters are laughibly cheesy and I have no desire to hear what they have to say. Thankfully you can end phone calls.

---{ Game Time }---
-I'm sure you can get plenty of game time out of this game considering the amount of cars and unlocks, but being 16 hours in, I feel like I'm already over the game and it's grind. Considering how, in my opinion, boring the actual open world aspect is, there isn't much of a reason for me to play this outside of something like FM7 or even FH5. They're very similar in the grind, but at least with FH5 there is substance in the world. With FM7, there is no free roam, however it's strickly focused on cars, tracks, and upgrades, which lends itself extremely well to the grind. To me, the map and free roam would be the only reason to play this over those other two options, but again, the free roam is soulless.

---{ Price }---
Price is fair, however I would only recommend picking up at half off. You get a lot of content for $20, but the game is simply not interesting enough to hold my attention to experience all the content.

---{ Bugs }---
I haven't ran into too many bugs outside of AI racers completely glitching out remaining stationary for the rest of the race. Considering my frustrations with the gameplay, I gladly embraced this bug and would take the free win.

---{ Replayability }---
As mentioned in game time. There is a decent amount here, but IMO, even if you unlocked all the content, it would likely be an uninstall after that. There are daily races and events, but they're really not that much different that what you would normally find on the map.

---{ Microtransactions }---
I think this game only has paid DLC, which I do appreciate

This is one of those cases where a 'neutral' review option would be great.

CarX Street isn't terrible. It's not great, either. It sits somewhere in-between, and how much you'll enjoy it depends on many things.

For one thing, there's a wide variety of cars in the game. And tuning options, so, so many tuning options.

But there's also a lack of certain options (controls, for example) as well as very janky physics when using a controller. I had purchased this game some time ago and ended up refunding it due to bad performance and major gamedesign and balancing issues at the time. Now I go to play it for a couple more hours thanks to the free weekend promo. And once again I was just about to give up on the game when, on a whim, I decided to give it a try using my Logitech G25 and SHH Thorn Shifter.

Much to my surprise, not only did the game recognize all of my devices (I have a Symprojects GT Wheelplate with four extra buttons mounted to my G25), but the FFB out of the box was pretty damn good. Not AMS2 levels of good, but much better than you'd expect from this sort of game. Sadly, there's no support for headtracking like TrackIR, though - that would be great to have.

The downside here is that there's not much in the ways of configuring the FFB, either. So aside from its strength, what you see is what you get.

While the performance has considerably improved since the early days, it's still not optimal and a little inconsistent. Even worse, the game just doesn't look all that good. The visuals and entire aesthetics of the city give strong PS3-era vibes, IMHO. There's also no DLSS, FSR or XESS - the "best" anti-aliasing you get is TAA! And don't get me started on the texture filtering... Whenever you view a surface at an angle - like the road surface, for example - it just gets all blurry. Yikes.

Moreover, the game has some weird design choices. Paying for fuel and tires, I'm okay with that. Each set of tires (5 complete sets per purchase) last quite a while, as does gas. But having to pay to get a car into each of the clubs in order to partake in their races - using that particular car - and then having to pay that fee again if you happen to switch clubs with that car is just... Stupid. It doesn't make sense.

Additionally, the races can be hit and miss. Sometimes the experience is utterly fantastic - you fight hard to evade traffic, then you run wide in a corner, have cut through a parking lot and just pray you'll fit through that gap between parked cars to get back onto the road... Oh so satisfying when it works.

And then you get T-boned by a truck coming at you from a blind spot at a 100+ miles while you are trying to go around a corner. Or pushed off the track by the relentless AI. Again. And again. (To be fair, AI drivers also get into accidents, so the traffic can be a curse or a blessing to the player, depending on how well you manage to evade it.)

And drifting... Oh boy, it's bad. First off, the game starts you off with a couple of cars that are just completely unsuited for drifting due to a lack of power. And you don't have much in terms of upgrade options early on. And apparently the game only rates the maximum angle of your drift, with no consideration for speed or anything else. Using a controller, I found proper drifting impossible no matter which of the three modes (full assists, partial assists, no assists) I used. But contrary to driving and racing it's still not much better with a wheel, sadly.

The game also feels very grindy early on. The starter cars have horrible handling and bad performance, and it takes a while until you unlock and can afford your first C2 (the second class) car, which is somewhat better already.

Last but not least, the game also still lacks in the audio department. Engine sounds aren't all that great, IMHO. And what little dialogue there is in the game is AI generated.

tl;dr some parts of the game (tuning, racing) can be fun - especially when using a steering wheel and H-Shifter - performance and visuals are mid at best, audio is somewhat sub-par, and there are still various strange choices in terms of game design. I'm keeping an eye on this, as the developers are known to keep working on their games for a long time to squash bugs, add content and features and generally improve their product on the long run (see Drift Racing Online for example).

Right now, though? I still can't fully recommend this game (yet).

I would not spend money on this game.

First big reason is the early game. C1 and C2 are incredibly difficult; where your victory in those classes will essentially come down to transmission gearing. In my case, because I was too low of a level to swap transmissions, I had to buy 2 different vehicles with different gearing in order to find success. I eventually found it, and that made the racing feel very competitive. At those low classes; every car understeers like crazy. There is very little you can do about it. Every car also feels very unstable at high speed; however as I am not really seeing that in other reviews, that could just be a skill issue on my part. 

Vehicle classes are determined by power to weight ratio; which I think is very good. This leaves a lot of room for suspension and handling upgrades without upping your vehicle class which I really like. 

The next big reason that I would not spend money on this game is it's heavy reliance on AI generated assets. All of the character portraits are AI gen, most of the artwork found within the open world is AI gen, I could be wrong but the voice acting also appears to all be AI gen. The first 30 min-hour of the game is very dialogue heavy, and the voice work was so grating that I skipped all of it. I can tell you nothing about the story and world building because the voices are so aggravating to listen to. 

I read a lot of the reviews about the game performing poorly; however that was not the case with me. During the intro cinematic, my game was stuttering awfully; however once that cinematic was over my game has had absolutely 0 performance issues. The initial load time is very long, however once you get past that and into the world, the game has pretty quick loading times. So; your mileage definitely seems to vary in this department. 

The city is pretty fun to explore; however it does lack a cohesive identity. Some parts feel like they are ripped straight out of Japan, and other areas feel like the US midwest. It is very, very strange. 

Exploration of the city is nicely rewarded; with the simple act of freely roaming the map granting you small amounts of in-game currency. The collectibles are pretty easy to find, and they are very well rewarded. 

It is rather grindy for currency; however I have found that participating in the vehicle deliveries is a very nice and not mind-numbing way to grind for currency. You get a low amount of currency simply for completing the delivery, however you can still collect the free-roam collectibles. This allows you to experience a wide variety of vehicles at no cost; and also netting you anywhere from 5k-30k per delivery depending on how many collectibles you run into along the way. Obviously this doesn't work long term as there are a finite number of collectibles, however it has been very nice for the early game as I try  a variety of vehicles to get through the difficulty of C1 and C2. 

Visually, the game looks good. What I like most in racing games is the ability to customize; which is why I will probably continue to play this game during the free weekend. CarX as a company are very good with the ability to customize vehicles. 

Ultimately; my lack of recommendation comes from the reliance on AI generated content; and the early game vehicle performance. Those both combined have made for a very exhausting 4 hours.

Car Physics: It's decent, the physics isn't at a racing sim level, but isn't entirely arcade like. It's sort of a bridge between arcade and simulator physics.

Graphics: This game would've had decent graphics if it wasn't for the glitched reflections and the aggressive occlusion culling resulting in buildings and props popping in when driving.

Gameplay: The gameplay is fine until you check the dealer ship for different cars, some C2 class cars require you to be lvl 16+, given the abysmal amount of XP you get after every club race it would take 50+ races to get the required XP to unlock certain cars.
